title: How should a beginner start writing songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Remember that song structure is not the same as poetry. There are verses, choruses and the bridge in the traditional pop song. The verses tell the story, the chorus (usually the same each time or with some variations and the same structure) which traditionally contains “the hook”, which is the main, usually title, of the song. The music of the choruses are usually the same as each other and the verses are usually the same as each other, but the bridge is usually a different section which is often only repeated once and it sort of drives home the “story” in the song. Now, this is a very basic, formulaic song and there are MANY exceptions. Buying and using a rhyming dictionary is a help when you are using a rhyming scheme and just cannot come up with that right word. Next, really study how the songwriters you most want to emulate structure their songs, especially compared to the “formula” I described. Perhaps that is not how you wish to write (because this is just one type of song structure of many). Listen to songs that you don’t know well and analyze their structure. In most cases, you do NOT want a long instrumental introduction, if you are writing a pop song. Unless you are Freddie Mercury, or of that caliber, avoid a song being over 3:45–4:00 long (look at the time of the songs you most enjoy). Most pop songs are even a few seconds shorter than the time I suggested. Once you start writing and studying this formulaic songs, you can move onto creating your own writing style because you have a good basis from which to start. Diane Warren has written many, many hits for top artists, so look up her discography and listen with a learning approach to how the structure of her songs is similar to each other and start from there. You should keep a journal with you all of the time and when you get song idea, write it down immediately. If you are sleeping, or almost asleep and come up with an idea, write it down NOW, not after you’ve slept because you could well forget it. This is how our production company worked with promising songwriters. We also put them with established writers to help improve their writing. As for the music part, we would hear what people wrote and then helped them edit the song, as opposed to giving them as much direction as the lyrics. So, with writing both music and lyrics, try to work with someone (network to find someone with whom you “click”) and that should help. There are many seminars, contests, etc. about songwriting too. This is just a really basic place to start. Once you get started, you will find your way to your own style. Best of luck.

There is no right or wrong way to start writing so here are a few suggestions for you to try. Journal at the end of each day. Start writing how you feel about your day, what went well, what was disappointing, what did you learn. Just write in your own words and don’t think about it too much. When you’ve done this for a week or two look back at the previous weeks journal entries and see if there’s any themes or phrases that jump out at you. These could be used for song titles, themes or lyrics. It’s a great way of finding your own writing style.Analyse songs you like. It takes a bit of music theory but it can really help to get your creative juices flowing. It helps you learn the rules of songwriting so you can learn to break them later. If you don't know enough music theory to do this have a look on YouTube, There’s lot’s of great videos analysing songs on their. Have a look at this analysis of Skyfall by Adele for example. goo.gl/7UxGwRRecord any melodies you come up with throughout your day. It doesn’t have to be fancy, the voice recorder in your smart phone will work. Keep doing this regularly and you’ll have plenty of melodies as a starting point for writing your next song. These are only starting points, you’ll have to add other melodies too them, add the chords and the lyrics but it’s a great starting point.Immerse yourself in learning songwriting and writing in general. Read poetry, read books, watch lessons on YouTube etc. Songwriting is a skill that takes time to learn, don’t let the size of the skill stop you from starting. Just writing a line a day is great progress. It might take you months to finish your first song but you’ll get much better over time. The more you write the better you’ll get.Hope those suggestions help. Good luck

There is no single formula for song writing. You need to find your own way. Some do the music first, some the lyrics. If you are a music-first person, explore your instrument(s) and find elements of a personal style—for instance I remember reading how Dave Matthews started out experimenting with the idea that the guitar can play a sort of bass line on the deep strings and moving harmonies on the higher ones. Some great songs just flow out of the writer in a flash—takes as long to complete as it does to perform. Others require weeks or months of study and revision. If lyrics first, carry a notebook around and write down every idea you get—then revisit them, rewrite them. Understand that every good writer edits the living hell out of the words, and remember the dictum “murder your darlings”—which means no matter how much you love a particular turn of phrase, you must be ready, even eager, to erase it if it doesn’t fit. Take solace that it may fit in another song. Read up on how the songwriters you admire do the work. Be an honest critic with yourself. Be OK with the notion that your first efforts are going to be pretty raw and unsophisticated. Keep working. I recall Bruce Hornsby talking about his hit “The Way It Is” and he observed that he wanted to write that song for a long time but first he had to grow as a songwriter, earlier in his career he wasn’t up to it. It’s an idea to block out a period of time every day to dedicate to writing. If you can, make it an hour or more during your best time of day.

Just write. Anything and everything.Finish your songs, even the bad ones. A song you think is bad can turn out to be good, but a song you don’t finish will forever be a song you didn’t finish. Sometimes all it takes is just spending a little more time on it. Essentially, you are building a piece of work from nothing. Rome wasn’t built in a day. Sit down, brainstorm if it helps, and just start writing. I usually write poems, and since I’ve studied songwriting and theory, I usually have an idea of how the song will be laid out lyrically. From there, I typically come up with some sort of thing on the guitar and just play it and sing the words however it comes to me at that point in time. I know not everyone writes the same, and you should really just try a few different approaches and see what works best for you. Learning an instrument will definitely help too. Good luck!

Don’t sit around asking strangers how to get started. Get started. Make something. it may be a bit crappy but if you put real passion into it, talent will show. Get started.Write em,Sing em (oh you have to do this or you can’t write em),Publish em (YouTube or Soundcloud then Bandcamp when you have an EP or album).Get feedback from good people (not people who will just flatter you as that is useless to damaging) andDo it again.Get a teacher. Not one of those teach creepy show children but someone who has gone where you want to go before and is now sharing their craft with others. Don’t worry about Genre. I learned more in a few months sitting with a Classically trained pianner pokin’ person than I did alone in a decade. I went to him with my material and asked him to help me get better. He had me learn some basics then we worked on how to improve my thing. I did and still feel I understand things better from that time (and money spent). Conversely, while I am a great self-learner I learn very little from most sparkly Tuts on YouTube. All froth, no content.

George M. Cohan wrote a hit song ‘Venus, My Shining Love’ when he was 13 or 14. I say you should write a few songs without academic knowledge. You can only do this once with a fresh few of songs (and totally clueless). But this can yield some amazing pieces. I would also say that start writing it from the area of your passion first. Whether it is words and lyrics or certain notes and tones or just fooling around on a keyboard or guitar. Then take that nugget of song Idea and work and work it into completion. Forever searching for that next perfect puzzle piece. GL

There are pieces to a song, namely lyrics and sounds. Most people have no problem coming up with words in their head they can sing. The real challenge is actually creating the beat or composition for which to sing lyrics over. As a beginner, I recommend my online course. Here are a couple of tips that could help: learn about the most common song structures: verse/chorus/verse/chorus/middle eight/chorus/chorususe simple 4 chord chord-progressions and practice finding different melodies on the same chord progressionpractice finding a chorus first (music and lyrics) and then write/compose the verseswrite from the title: come up with a title first (which usually will be the most important line in your chorus, containing the main message of the song) then write the verses (which should give the listener the context, details, images and storyline that supports the CHORUS and message of the song)

Some ideas… 1 Write something every day- whatever comes to mind. Just work on it 2 Write new melodies to existing lyrics you like, and vice versa 3 Rewrite some of the weaker songs you hear and think are bad (as an exercise only- don’t try to pass them off as yours, unless you totally recreate them. Even then it could be risky.)
